<section class="col-12 col-md-11 col-lg-9 content-section rounded-2 border" data-markdown="true" data-markdown-text="To remove a GitHub project directory using the GitHub API with JavaScript, you'll need to follow these steps:

1. **Get the contents of the directory** using the GitHub API's `GET /repos/{owner}/{repo}/contents/{path}` endpoint.
2. **Delete each file** in the directory using the GitHub API's `DELETE /repos/{owner}/{repo}/contents/{path}` endpoint.

Here’s a basic guide to implement this:

### Step 1: Get Directory Contents
You need to first retrieve the contents of the directory you want to delete, including file paths and their SHA values, as these are required to delete files.

```javascript
async function getDirectoryContents(owner, repo, directoryPath, token) {
    const url = `https://api.github.com/repos/${owner}/${repo}/contents/${directoryPath}`;
    
    const response = await fetch(url, {
        method: 'GET',
        headers: {
            'Authorization': `token ${token}`,
            'Accept': 'application/vnd.github.v3+json',
        },
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
        throw new Error('Failed to get directory contents');
    }

    return await response.json();
}
```

### Step 2: Delete Files
After retrieving the files, loop through each one and delete it using the `DELETE /repos/{owner}/{repo}/contents/{path}` API endpoint. You need the file path and the SHA hash of each file for this operation.

```javascript
async function deleteFile(owner, repo, filePath, sha, token) {
    const url = `https://api.github.com/repos/${owner}/${repo}/contents/${filePath}`;
    
    const response = await fetch(url, {
        method: 'DELETE',
        headers: {
            'Authorization': `token ${token}`,
            'Accept': 'application/vnd.github.v3+json',
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        },
        body: JSON.stringify({
            message: `Deleting ${filePath}`,
            sha: sha,
        }),
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
        throw new Error(`Failed to delete file: ${filePath}`);
    }

    return await response.json();
}
```

### Step 3: Combine Functions
Now, you can combine the functions to get the directory contents and delete each file.

```javascript
async function deleteDirectory(owner, repo, directoryPath, token) {
    try {
        const contents = await getDirectoryContents(owner, repo, directoryPath, token);

        // Check if it's a directory and contains files
        if (Array.isArray(contents)) {
            for (const item of contents) {
                if (item.type === 'file') {
                    await deleteFile(owner, repo, item.path, item.sha, token);
                } else if (item.type === 'dir') {
                    // Recursively delete subdirectories
                    await deleteDirectory(owner, repo, item.path, token);
                }
            }
        }

        console.log(`Directory ${directoryPath} deleted successfully`);
    } catch (error) {
        console.error(`Error deleting directory: ${error.message}`);
    }
}
```

### Step 4: Usage Example
Use your GitHub personal access token and call the `deleteDirectory` function:

```javascript
const owner = 'your-github-username';
const repo = 'your-repository-name';
const directoryPath = 'path/to/your/directory';
const token = 'your-personal-access-token';

deleteDirectory(owner, repo, directoryPath, token);
```

### Notes:
- Ensure you have proper access rights to the repository.
- You need to specify a commit message when deleting a file via the API.
- GitHub's API works recursively for directories, so if there are subdirectories, they will be handled as well.

This script will delete all files and subdirectories in the specified path."></section>
